docs.lead_paragraph: For some people who suffer from recurring headaches, the culprit could be as close as the sandwich in their hands or the pasta on their plates. That's because gluten, a component of wheat and other grains from which flour is made, may cause headaches in people with gluten sensitivity, researchers report.

headline.main: Headache May Lurk Inside a Sandwich

docs.abstract: Researchers report eating gluten, grain component from which flour is made, may cause headaches in people with gluten sensitivity; drawing
docs.snippet: For some people who suffer from recurring headaches, the culprit could be as close as the sandwich in their hands or the pasta on their plates.    That's because gluten, a component of wheat and other grains from which flour is made, may cause...

docs.lead_paragraph: Of the estimated 730,000 Americans who have strokes each year, nearly 160,000 die and another 400,000 suffer varying degrees of disability. Yet, when stroke patients arrive at emergency rooms, medical experts say, they are not usually treated with the urgency required. The less-than-rapid response, in some cases, can make the difference between full recovery and permanent debilitating disease or death.

headline.main: Absence of Urgency: A Deadly Problem When Strokes Occur

docs.abstract: Experts say stroke victims are not usually treated with required urgency in emergency rooms; say rapid treatment with anti-clotting drug TPA can make difference between full recovery and permanent disability or death, but only 2 to 3 percent of stroke patients get drug; diagram; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Of the estimated 730,000 Americans who have strokes each year, nearly 160,000 die and another 400,000 suffer varying degrees of disability. Yet, when stroke patients arrive at emergency rooms, medical experts say, they are not usually treated with...

docs.lead_paragraph: There may be no bellowing at your workplace or no heavy equipment rumbling back and forth, but don't equate the relative quiet with a lack of stress. A new study by researchers from Cornell has found that even low-level noise in an open-style office setting can lead to measurably higher levels of stress.

headline.main: When a Steady Buzz Spells Steady Stress

docs.abstract: Prof Gary W Evans and Dana Johnson report that even low-level noise in open-style office can lead to measurably higher levels of stress; find workers in offices with low-level noise make fewer efforts to adjust their workstations than those in quiet offices, making them more susceptible to problems like repetitive strain injury; find noise does not affect performance; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: There may be no bellowing at your workplace or no heavy equipment rumbling back and forth, but don't equate the relative quiet with a lack of stress.    A new study by researchers from Cornell has found that even low-level noise in an open-style...

docs.lead_paragraph: An arsenal of 15 drugs would seem ample to treat a disease successfully. But not AIDS. Since the mid-1980's, scientists have developed 15 drugs directed against H.I.V., the AIDS virus. Combinations of three or more of the anti-H.I.V. drugs have reduced the number of deaths and allowed thousands of infected people to maintain relatively good health. With improved obstetrical care, the drugs have sharply reduced the incidence of mother-to-child transmission of H.I.V. in the United States and Europe to less than 2 percent from earlier highs of 25 percent.

headline.main: To Combat the Wily H.I.V., Newer and Safer Drugs Are Necessary

docs.abstract: AIDS experts at conference, Chicago, warn that HIV, AIDS virus, is so wily that drugs are still failing thousands of infected people, including many who have taken each of existing 15 anti-HIV drugs at one time or another; call for new, safer drugs; say ultimate goals include once-daily combination that avoids irreversibly damaging immune system and delays disease progression; note many candidate drugs are in various stages of development; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite recent growth of the hospice field, intended to help the terminally ill die as peacefully as possible, most Americans still die in hospitals. Other studies had found that doctors often failed to tell patients' families about their options; now, a new report suggests that nurses, too, may play a role. In the current issue of The Journal of Professional Nursing, researchers reported that more than half the nurses studied in a hospital setting said they never discussed hospice care with their patients.

headline.main: Sounds of Silence on Hospice Options

docs.abstract: Study in Journal of Professional Nursing finds that over half of nurses studied in hospital setting never discussed hospice care with terminally ill patients; says many lack key knowledge about hospice and palliative care (S)
docs.snippet: Despite recent growth of the hospice field, intended to help the terminally ill die as peacefully as possible, most Americans still die in hospitals. Other studies had found that doctors often failed to tell patients' families about their options;...

docs.lead_paragraph: For residents of colder climes, this is not a happy time of year for body surfaces that depend upon moisture to remain pliable, comfortable and intact. Winter air, both indoors and out, is low in humidity, which results in a steady loss of moisture from the skin.

headline.main: Saving Your Skin When Winter Attacks

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on protecting skin from loss of moisture in winter (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Only about one in five diabetics takes regular doses of aspirin to help prevent heart disease, even though people with diabetes are at much greater risk of developing it, a new study has found. Diabetics are two to four times as likely to develop heart disease as those without diabetes, the American Diabetes Association reports. A person with Type 2 diabetes has the same risk of a heart attack as a nondiabetic who has had an attack.
docs.abstract: Study finds only about one in five diabetics takes regular doses of aspirin to help prevent heart disease, even though people with diabetes are at much greater risk of developing it (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Exercise, even late in life, has repeatedly been found to improve people's health in a number of ways, including reducing the risk of heart disease and broken bones. Now, a new study suggests that regular exercise may also help older people ward off disease by strengthening their immune systems.

headline.main: Work Out at 80? Experts See the Gains

docs.abstract: New Dutch study finds regular exercise may help aged ward off disease by strenghtening their immune systems; drawing (M)
